item.title: A car that automatically slows you down
item.description: Vehicles in London could soon be fitted with technology that would automatically slow them down if they break the speed limit.

item.title: Student faces expulsion for Web post
item.description: This school is overstepping its bounds. They are disciplining this guy for something he posted outside of school hours. Don't they have better things to do? Maybe they should try educating students instead of prosecuting students.

item.title: Is Windows On a Mac Really Drawing in New Users
item.description: Yes. Check it out.

item.title: How-To: Build yourself a front projection home theater
item.description: "In today's How-To we get to play with other people's toys. We upgraded a home theater to a high definition front projection system. We lay it out, set it up, drill holes, nearly die in a Texas attic, and bring home the popcorn."

item.title: Costly Porn Filter: Spam Filter Costs School Board $250,000
item.description: Cobb County School officials are blaming an overeager junk-mail filter for capturing and killing a Kennesaw businessman's bid to provide telephone services to the system. It seems the part of the filter that watches for pornographic material was offended by the use of terms such as "long distance."

item.title: More Rounded Corners with CSS
item.description: "Admit it. You know it, your Mom knows it and even your Grandmother probably knows it by now: Rounded corners, borders and drop shadows (while nothing new) are all the rage these days on the 'Web 2.0, fully Ajaxed, Ajax-enhanced, Ajaxified' Web 2.0-era Web."

item.title: Teenager repellent "Mosquito" turned into ringtone
item.description: Techno-savvy UK pupils have recorded the ultra-high sound - audible only to under-20-year-olds - from the ultrasonic device Mosquito onto their cell phones - and are now receiving calls and text messages in class without teachers having the faintest idea of what is going on.

item.title: Technorati Teams With The Associated Press
item.description: Technorati and the Associated Press this morning initiated a service to connect bloggers to more than 440 AP member newspapers nationwide.

item.title: Microsoft Updates Its Windows Server Roadmap
item.description: Expect Longhorn Server Beta 3 in the first half of next year, but no Windows Server 'Centro' for mid-size businesses until 2008. And there might be a Windows Server Branch Office in the future, after all.

item.title: Sony to prevent selling of pre-owned PS3 games?
item.description: So Daily Radar is reporting -- apparently users will 'rent' games rather than buy them. Right...

item.title: Vonage Hopes To Raise $531 Million In IPO
item.description: Internet phone service provider Vonage Holdings on Tuesday priced its initial public offering at $17 per share, for a total value of about $531 million.

item.title: Dell Strikes Back
item.description: It looks like some of us will not be needing to wipe the OS from our Dell systems anymore. I hope they extend this no software install to the cheaper computers to.

item.title: Ballmer Hints at Possible Further Vista Delay!
item.description: Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer has played down the recent slide in the software giant's share price but hinted at a possible further delay to the release of its new operating system.

item.title: Voyager 2 Detects Odd Shape of Solar System's Edge
item.description: Voyager 2 could pass beyond the outermost layer of our solar system, called the "termination shock," sometime within the next year, NASA scientists announced at a media teleconference today.

item.title: Mathematical Proofs turned into Music
item.description: "While looking at some proofs, it occurred to me that their structure resembled musical scores, so as an experiment I decided to see what they sounded like. Essentially, the musical notes correspond to the depth of the proof tree as the proof is constructed by the proof verifier."

item.title: New domain launched for mobile phones
item.description: Web browsing on portable phones still has some way to go before it is as useful and convenient as browsing from a PC, but a new industry consortium wants to change all that. Their plan? Introduce another top level domain called ".mobi", which will feature content formatted for mobile devices.

item.title: Coming Soon: XBOX 360 Modchips
item.description: Team Xecuter thought that those hackers shouldn't be the only ones to be able to play backup games for the XBOX 360 game console, and has announced that the group is very close to releasing a first generation mod-chip for XBOX 360.

item.title: The Ethical Dilemmas of Immortality
item.description: several ethical and moral arguments that have cropped up in recent years as labs around the world aim at the dream of immortality, or at least to extend lives well beyond the century mark.

item.title: Apple accidently releases "Dashcode"
item.description:
After receiving a new Macbook Pro and installing the included developer tools, a curious application made an appearance under /Developer/Applications. You can download Apple's widget creation tool here: http://filebucket.org/71g871e712/102/Dashcode.tar.bz2
This is NOT included in Xcode 2.3

item.title: PGP creator offers VoIP crypto to Windows users
item.description: Philip Zimmermann, best known as the developer of the Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) encryption algorithm, has released a new public beta of a software package designed to encrypt VoIP calls.

item.title: The Geek Who Took On Microsoft
item.description: Peter Quinn, The mild-mannered CIO of Massachusetts sparked a standards debate when he made it policy that state workers use open-standard formats.

item.title: Just Released: Insider Information on NSA Wiretaps
item.description: " ...the N.S.A. began to eavesdrop on callers...or to investigate them using traditional police methods. A government consultant told me that tens of thousands of Americans had had their calls monitored in one way or the other. [...] the Administration, by not approaching the FISA court early on, had made it much harder to go to the court later."

item.title: Saving Superman from Hollywood
item.description: The mild-mannered director behind the X-Men movies is on a mission to save Superman from the Hollywood hacks.

item.title: Gizmondo - the UK gaming firm that wasted £160 million in 18 months
item.description: In the words of Paul Davis of Begbies Traynor, one of the firms appointed as liquidators of Gizmondo: “No matter how much you spend on cars, watches and directors’ perks, you just can’t get through a sum as big as this quite as quickly as Gizmondo did.”

item.title: Apple´s sudden motion sensor in action.
item.description: Desktop manager/motion sensor hack for MacBook Pro

item.title: Human-To-Human Bird Flu Suspected In Indonesia
item.description: Seven Indonesian Bird Flu Cases Linked to Patients...

item.title: Americans bet 4 billion dollars online despite ban
item.description: US residents spent more than four billion dollars last year on Internet gambling, despite a de facto prohibition on such wagering in the United States, according to a report.The American Gaming Association said its analysis supports the need for a congressional study of ways to regulate online gambling for US residents.

item.title: Google's Surprise Investor Meeting
item.description: Google plans to hold a special meeting with financial analysts and investors next week, in a bid to improve the company's rocky relations with Wall Street.

item.title: 1000+ public domain images
item.description: Scanned remains of castles, deserted abbeys, old manor houses, mansions and stately homes; also engravings, woodcuts and pictures of Old England and Wales. Most are public domain unless otherwise noted, and can be used as historical reference in teaching, royalty-free stock images, scrapbook clip art and/or on websites.

item.title: Island-hopping virus' ferocity exposed
item.description: Scientists have found clues as to why a little-known virus is disabling hundreds of thousands of Indian Ocean island dwellers, in an outbreak that threatens to spread further around the world.

item.title: Study Finds No Link between Marijuana and Lung Cancer
item.description: A marijuana cigarette also deposits four times as much of that tar as an equivalent tobacco one. Scientists were therefore surprised to learn that a study of more than 2,000 people found no increase in the risk of developing lung cancer for marijuana smokers.

item.title: Build a Powerful Water Balloon Launcher (with Video)
item.description: Want to shoot an object at 140 MPH over 500ft? Then this launcher is for you! This article will teach you how to build one of the cheapest, easiest, and most powerful water balloon launchers ever invented.

item.title: Study: Video games can help cut surgical errors
item.description: Surgeons who warmed up by playing video games like "Super Monkey Ball" for 20 minutes immediately prior to performing surgical drills were faster and made fewer errors than those who did not.

item.title: Microsoft Releases Vista, Longhorn, Office Betas - Simultaneously
item.description: In an unprecedented move, Microsoft Tuesday simultaneously released beta versions of its three major upcoming software releases -- Windows Vista, Office 2007 and Windows Server, code-named Longhorn.

item.title: Thinking in Logarithms Can Be Natural
item.description: There are asymmetries in the way animals perceive numbers and time, and a recent experiment showed that pigeons underestimate the midpoint between two time intervals.

item.title: Google Summer of Code results are in! Drupal's 14 exciting projects
item.description: An XUL administration interface, AJAX forms creator, integration with the latest GData protocol and a Social Network Analysis tool are all on the roster of sponsored projects for the 2006 Summer of Code program. Thanks to Google for guaranteeing that 2006 will be the most exciting summer for Drupal - EVER!

item.title: Install the Vista Sidebar on XP - In One Package!
item.description: There have been hacks for a while now to allow people to install the Windows Vista sidebar by assembling files from various sources but I just stumbled across a single executable package that MSTN put together.

item.title: Microsoft: Use MS Word in Safe Mode
item.description: The software maker issues a security advisory with workarounds to limit the damage from zero-day attacks against Microsoft Word users.

item.title: FCC Will NOT Investigate AT&T/NSA Allegations
item.description: "If the FCC initiates an investigation and gets blocked by the White House, then the White House is stonewalling. But if the FCC refuses to even demand answers, then the White House never has to block the enforcement agency from getting to the bottom of this. The American people deserve answers."

item.title: Cops ask fiction writer for DNA after he posts a horror story online
item.description: "The police have repeatedly visited the student and demanded that he submit his fingerprints and DNA to them so that they can compare the fictional murder he described in his story to evidence from any similar unsolved murders." Sometimes your writing is TOO good...
